subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
Coined in 1953 by Prof. Cai Fangyin (蔡方蔭).<ref>[https://books.google.hu/books?id=NfN0DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA170&lpg=PA170&dq=%22Cai+Fangyin%22+concrete&source=bl&ots=PekDsLdwxd&sig=81E2e4yLh4RaUc5oJ-nngQQf4AE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj73_m2y5PfAhXCa1AKHSFWBmUQ6AEwB3oECAgQAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Cai%20Fangyin%22%20concrete&f=false Early 21st-Century Power Struggles of Chinese Languages Teaching in US Higher Education], by Ya-chen Chen, p. 170 (at Google Books)</ref>

The glyph is a compound of {{zh-l|[[人工]][[石]]|man-made stone}}. Pronunciation is from {{zh-l|仝}}, treated as the phonetic component of the glyph. Serendipitously, the pronunciation also resembles the word for “concrete” in some European languages; cf. {{cog|fr|béton}}, {{cog|de|Beton}}, {{cog|ru|бето́н}}.
